{"content":"The following is the commit files that have changed: [ { "sha": "211893c4c144d51d16da27454cc99c65ed8a9998", "filename": "docs/external-id/tenant-restrictions-v2.md", "status": "modified", "additions": 5, "deletions": 2, "changes": 7, "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/ecca2938dca70fa763c53bb867428f3db75c2edd/docs%2Fexternal-id%2Ftenant-restrictions-v2.md", "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/ecca2938dca70fa763c53bb867428f3db75c2edd/docs%2Fexternal-id%2Ftenant-restrictions-v2.md", "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fexternal-id%2Ftenant-restrictions-v2.md?ref=ecca2938dca70fa763c53bb867428f3db75c2edd", "patch": "@@ -679,9 +679,12 @@ Use Microsoft Graph to get policy information.\n \n ## Known limitations\n \n-Tenant restrictions v2 is supported on all clouds. However, tenant restrictions v2 is not enforced with cross-cloud requests.\n+- Tenant restrictions v2 is supported on all clouds. However, tenant restrictions v2 is not enforced with cross-cloud requests.\n+\n+- Tenant restrictions v2 doesn't work with the [macOS Platform SSO](~/identity/devices/troubleshoot-macos-platform-single-sign-on-extension.md) feature with client signaling via corporate proxy. Customers who use tenant restrictions v2 and Platform SSO should use universal tenant restrictions v2 with Global Secure Access client signaling. This is an Apple limitation in which Platform SSO is not compatible with tenant restrictions when an intermediary network solution injects headers. An example of such a solution is a proxy that uses a certificate trust chain outside Apple system root certificates.\n+\n+- When TRv2 is enabled, accessing the Microsoft Entra admin center may result in an \"Access denied\" error. To resolve this issue, append the following feature flags to the Microsoft Entra admin center URL: `?feature.msaljs=true&exp.msaljsexp=true`. If you're accessing the admin center for a partner tenant (e.g., Fabrikam) and encounter the error at `https://entra.microsoft.com/`, update the URL as follows: `https://entra.microsoft.com/?feature.msaljs=true&exp.msaljsexp=true#home`. This will enable the necessary flags and restore access.\n \n-Tenant restrictions v2 doesn't work with the [macOS Platform SSO](~/identity/devices/troubleshoot-macos-platform-single-sign-on-extension.md) feature with client signaling via corporate proxy. Customers who use tenant restrictions v2 and Platform SSO should use universal tenant restrictions v2 with Global Secure Access client signaling. This is an Apple limitation in which Platform SSO is not compatible with tenant restrictions when an intermediary network solution injects headers. An example of such a solution is a proxy that uses a certificate trust chain outside Apple system root certificates.\n \n ## Related content\n " }, { "sha": "cdf1573a0191491797dd5c7a3073ac39658c52b4", "filename": "docs/fundamentals/copilot-entra-security-scenarios.md", "status": "modified", "additions": 26, "deletions": 2, "changes": 28, "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/ecca2938dca70fa763c53bb867428f3db75c2edd/docs%2Ffundamentals%2Fcopilot-entra-security-scenarios.md", "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/ecca2938dca70fa763c53bb867428f3db75c2edd/docs%2Ffundamentals%2Fcopilot-entra-security-scenarios.md", "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Ffundamentals%2Fcopilot-entra-security-scenarios.md?ref=ecca2938dca70fa763c53bb867428f3db75c2edd", "patch": "@@ -28,7 +28,7 @@ Security Copilot is a part of the Microsoft Entra admin center, and you can use\n | Microsoft Entra ID | [Tenants](#tenants)

Microsoft Entra Private Access | [License Usage](#license-usage) |\n+| Microsoft Entra Internet Access
Microsoft Entra Private Access | [License Usage](#license-usage)
[Global Secure Access](#global-secure-access) |\n \n ## Microsoft Entra ID\n \n@@ -438,7 +438,7 @@ Refer to the prompts and examples in [Manage employee lifecycle using Microsoft\n \n ## Microsoft Entra Internet Access and Private Access\n \n-The following sections describe how to use Microsoft Security Copilot for scenarios and use cases within Global Secure Access.\n+The following sections describe how to use Microsoft Security Copilot for scenarios and use cases within Microsoft Entra Internet Access and Private Access.\n \n ### License Usage \n \n@@ -456,6 +456,30 @@ For more information, see:\n \n - [Microsoft Entra licensing](/entra/fundamentals/licensing)\n \n+### Global Secure Access\n+\n+Microsoft Security Copilot supports network traffic logs in Global Secure Access, making it easier to investigate and monitor network traffic usage and behavior. \n+\n+This enhancement provides an interactive method for analyzing network traffic logs, allowing users to obtain valuable insights without the need to write complex queries. Users can analyze user, device, and branch network usage, identify network issues, and detect threats or policy violations in real time. As a result, the investigation process is significantly streamlined and more effective. \n+\n+Users assigned the following roles can use this feature:\n+\n+- [Security Administrator](/entra/identity/role-based-access-control/permissions-reference#security-administrator)\n+- [Global Reader](/entra/identity/role-based-access-control/permissions-reference#global-reader)\n+- [Global Secure Access Administrator](/entra/identity/role-based-access-control/permissions-reference#global-secure-access-administrator)\n+- [Global Secure Access Log Reader](/entra/identity/role-based-access-control/permissions-reference#global-secure-access-log-reader). \n+\n+You will also need a [Microsoft Entra ID P1 or P2 license](/entra/id-protection/overview-identity-protection#license-requirements), an Entra Private Access License (for private access traffic), Entra Internet Access License (for general internet traffic outside Microsoft services). Your tenant must also have Global Secure Access configured and Microsoft Security Copilot enabled.\n+\n+The following example prompts can be used to investigate network traffic logs in Microsoft Entra:\n+\n+- *Show the top 5 users with the highest data consumption in the last day.*\n+- *Show all blocked traffic for user {user principal name} in the last 24 hours.*\n+- *List all applications with high-risk scores accessed in the last 24 hours.*\n+- *List all applications that user {user principal name} has accessed in the last 24 hours based on network traffic.*\n+- *List of the top 10 accessed applications in the last week.*\n+- *Show all cross-tenant traffic to tenant {Enter_Tenant_ID_Here} in the last day.* \n+\n ## See also\n \n - [Get started with Microsoft Security Copilot](/copilot/security/get-started-security-copilot)" }, { "sha": "1393d837989c1369d9bdf1668c0517b19e0bc715", "filename": "docs/identity/authentication/concept-authentication-strength-advanced-options.md", "status": "modified", "additions": 16, "deletions": 16, "changes": 32, "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/ecca2938dca70fa763c53bb867428f3db75c2edd/docs%2Fidentity%2Fauthentication%2Fconcept-authentication-strength-advanced-options.md", "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/ecca2938dca70fa763c53bb867428f3db75c2edd/docs%2Fidentity%2Fauthentication%2Fconcept-authentication-strength-advanced-options.md", "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fidentity%2Fauthentication%2Fconcept-authentication-strength-advanced-options.md?ref=ecca2938dca70fa763c53bb867428f3db75c2edd", "patch": "@@ -1,10 +1,10 @@\n ---\n-title: Overview of custom authentication strengths and advanced options for FIDO2 security keys and certificate-based authentication in Microsoft Entra ID\n-description: Learn how admins can create custom authentication strengths with advanced options for FIDO2 security keys and certificate-based authentication.\n+title: Overview of custom authentication strengths and advanced options for passkey (FIDO2) and certificate-based authentication in Microsoft Entra ID\n+description: Learn how admins can create custom authentication strengths with advanced options for passkey (FIDO2) security keys and certificate-based authentication.\n ms.service: entra-id\n ms.subservice: authentication\n ms.topic: article\n-ms.date: 03/04/2025\n+ms.date: 09/15/2025\n ms.author: justinha\n author: inbarckms\n manager: dougeby\n@@ -31,12 +31,12 @@ You can edit a custom authentication strength. If it's referenced by a Condition\n To check if an authentication strength is referenced by a Conditional Access policy, click the **Conditional Access policies** column.\n \n \n-## FIDO2 security key advanced options\n-You can restrict the usage of FIDO2 security keys based on their Authenticator Attestation GUIDs (AAGUIDs). This capability allows administrators to require a FIDO2 security key from a specific manufacturer in order to access the resource. To require a specific FIDO2 security key, first create a custom authentication strength. Then select **FIDO2 Security Key**, and click **Advanced options**. \n+## Passkey (FIDO2) advanced options\n+You can restrict the usage of passkeys (FIDO2) based on their Authenticator Attestation GUIDs (AAGUIDs). This capability allows administrators to require a FIDO2 security key from a specific manufacturer in order to access the resource. To require a specific FIDO2 security key, first create a custom authentication strength. Then select **Passkeys (FIDO2)**, and click **Advanced options**. \n \n-:::image type=\"content\" border=\"true\" source=\"./media/concept-authentication-strengths/key.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot showing Advanced options for FIDO2 security key.\":::\n+:::image type=\"content\" border=\"true\" source=\"./media/concept-authentication-strengths/key.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot showing Advanced options for passkey (FIDO2).\":::\n \n-Next to **Allowed FIDO2 Keys** click **+**, copy the AAGUID value, and click **Save**.\n+Next to **Add AAGUID**, click **+**, copy the AAGUID value, and click **Save**.\n \n :::image type=\"content\" border=\"true\" source=\"./media/concept-authentication-strengths/guid.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot showing how to add an Authenticator Attestation GUID.\":::\n \n@@ -62,12 +62,12 @@ The next sections show how to configure advanced options for CBA by using the Mi\n \n :::image type=\"content\" border=\"true\" source=\"./media/concept-authentication-strength-advanced-options/certificate-advanced-options.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot showing Advanced options for certificate-based authentication.\":::\n \n-1. You can select certificate issuers from the drop-down menu, type the certificate issuers and type the allowed policy OIDs. The drop-down menu lists all certificate authorities from the tenant irrespective of whether they're single-factor or multifactor. Certificate issuers can be configured either by using the drop down **Certificate issuers from the certificate authorities in your tenant** or by using **Other certificate issuer by SubjectkeyIdentifier** for scenarios where the certificate you would like to use is not uploaded to the Certificate authorities in your tenant. One such example is external user scenarios, where the user could be authenticating in their home tenant and auth strength is being enforced on the resource tenant.\n+1. You can select certificate issuers from the drop-down menu, type the certificate issuers and type the allowed policy OIDs. The drop-down menu lists all certificate authorities from the tenant irrespective of whether they're single-factor or multifactor. Certificate issuers can be configured either by using the drop-down **Certificate issuers from the certificate authorities in your tenant** or by using **Other certificate issuer by SubjectkeyIdentifier** for scenarios where the certificate you would like to use is not uploaded to the Certificate authorities in your tenant. One such example is external user scenarios, where the user could be authenticating in their home tenant and auth strength is being enforced on the resource tenant.\n \n- :::image type=\"content\" border=\"true\" source=\"./media/concept-authentication-strength-advanced-options/or-other-issuer.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot showing the configuration options - certificate issuers from the drop-down menu, type the certificate issuers and type the allowed policy OIDs .\":::\n+ :::image type=\"content\" border=\"true\" source=\"./media/concept-authentication-strength-advanced-options/or-other-issuer.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot showing the configuration options - certificate issuers from the drop-down menu, type the certificate issuers and type the allowed policy OIDs.\":::\n \n - If both attributes Certificate issuers AND Policy OIDs are configured, there's a AND relationship and the user has to use a certificate that has atleast one of the issuers AND one of the policy OID from the list to satisfy the authentication strength.\n- - If only Certificate issuers attribute is configured then the user has to use a certificate that has atleast one of the issuers to satisfy the authentication strength .\n+ - If only Certificate issuers attribute is configured then the user has to use a certificate that has atleast one of the issuers to satisfy the authentication strength.\n - If only Policy OIDs attribute is configured then the user has to use a certificate that has atleast one of the policy OIDs to satisfy the authentication strength.\n \n >[!NOTE]\n@@ -122,8 +122,8 @@ POST beta/identity/conditionalAccess/authenticationStrength/policies/{authentica\n \n ## Limitations\n \n-### FIDO2 security key advanced options\n-- FIDO2 security key Advanced options - Advanced options aren't supported for external users with a home tenant that is located in a different Microsoft cloud than the resource tenant.\n+### Passkeys (FIDO2) Advanced options\n+- Passkeys (FIDO2) Advanced options - Advanced options aren't supported for external users with a home tenant that is located in a different Microsoft cloud than the resource tenant.\n \n ### Certificate-based authentication advanced options\n \n@@ -136,7 +136,7 @@ POST beta/identity/conditionalAccess/authenticationStrength/policies/{authentica\n >[!NOTE]\n >If the certificate doesn't conform, user authentication might succeed, but not satisfy the issuerSki restrictions for the authentication strength policy.\n \n-- During sign-in, the first 5 policy OIDs from the end user certificate are considered, and compared with the policy OIDs configured in the authentication strength policy. If the end user certificate has more than 5 policy OIDs, the first 5 policy OIDs in lexical order that match the authentication strength requirements are taken into account. \n+- During sign-in, the first 5 policy OIDs from the end user certificate are considered, and compared with the policy OIDs configured in the authentication strength policy. If the end user certificate has more than five policy OIDs, the first five policy OIDs in lexical order that match the authentication strength requirements are taken into account. \n \n - For B2B users, let's take an example where Contoso has invited users from Fabrikam to their tenant. In this case, Contoso is the resource tenant and Fabrikam is the home tenant.\n - When cross-tenant access setting is **Off** (Contoso doesn't accept MFA that was performed by the home tenant) - Using certificate-based authentication on the resource tenant isn't supported.\n@@ -147,10 +147,10 @@ POST beta/identity/conditionalAccess/authenticationStrength/policies/{authentica\n \n ## Troubleshooting authentication strength advanced options\n \n-### Users can't use their FIDO2 security key to sign in\n-A Conditional Access Administrator can restrict access to specific security keys. When a user tries to sign in by using a key they can't use, this **You can't get there from here** message appears. The user has to restart the session, and sign-in with a different FIDO2 security key.\n+### Users can't use their passkey (FIDO2) to sign in\n+A Conditional Access Administrator can restrict access to specific security keys. When a user tries to sign in by using a key they can't use, this **You can't get there from here** message appears. The user has to restart the session, and sign-in with a different passkey (FIDO2).\n \n-:::image type=\"content\" border=\"true\" source=\"./media/troubleshoot-authentication-strengths/restricted-security-key.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot of a sign-in error when using a restricted FIDO2 security key.\":::\n+:::image type=\"content\" border=\"true\" source=\"./media/troubleshoot-authentication-strengths/restricted-security-key.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot of a sign-in error when using a restricted passkey (FIDO2).\":::\n \n \n ### How to check certificate policy OIDs and issuer" }, { "sha": "0857217b2eed61f077782986c4691ef8eb6312f0", "filename": "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/ecca2938dca70fa763c53bb867428f3db75c2edd/docs%2Fidentity%2Fconditional-access%2Fconcept-conditional-access-report-only.md", "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fidentity%2Fconditional-access%2Fconcept-conditional-access-report-only.md?ref=ecca2938dca70fa763c53bb867428f3db75c2edd", "patch": "@@ -1,29 +1,30 @@\n ---\n-title: Analyze Conditional Access policy impact\n-description: Analyze Conditional Access policy impact using report-only mode and other tools.\n+title: \"Conditional Access Policy Insights: Monitoring and Evaluation\"\n+description: Discover how to analyze Conditional Access policy results with tools like Azure Monitor and insights workbooks for better policy management.\n ms.service: entra-id\n ms.subservice: conditional-access\n ms.topic: article\n-ms.date: 03/12/2025\n+ms.date: 09/15/2025\n ms.author: joflore\n author: MicrosoftGuyJFlo\n manager: dougeby\n ms.reviewer: kvenkit\n ms.custom: sfi-image-nochange\n ---\n+\n # Analyze Conditional Access Policy Impact\n \n-Conditional Access helps organizations stay secure by applying the right security access controls under the right circumstances. Understanding the impact of these policies can be challenging, especially when deploying new policies. This article explains how to analyze Conditional Access policy impact using report-only mode and other tools.\n+Conditional Access helps organizations stay secure by applying the appropriate security access controls in the right circumstances. Understanding the impact of these policies is challenging, especially when deploying new policies. This article explains how to analyze the impact of Conditional Access policies using report-only mode and other tools.\n \n-There are several options available to administrators based on report-only mode. Report-only mode is a policy state letting administrators test most Conditional Access policies before enabling them.\n+Administrators have several options based on report-only mode. Report-only mode is a policy state that lets administrators test most Conditional Access policies before enabling them.\n \n-- Conditional Access policies can be evaluated in report-only mode except for items included in the \"User Actions\" scope.\n-- During sign-in, policies in report-only mode are evaluated but not enforced.\n+- Administrators can evaluate Conditional Access policies in report-only mode, except for items included in the \"User Actions\" scope.\n+- During sign-in, the system evaluates policies in report-only mode but doesn't enforce them.\n - Results are logged in the **Conditional Access** and **Report-only** tabs of the Sign-in log details.\n - Customers with an Azure Monitor subscription can monitor the impact of their Conditional Access policies using the Conditional Access insights workbook.\n \n > [!WARNING]\n-> Policies in report-only mode that require a compliant device might prompt users on macOS, iOS, and Android devices to select a device certificate during policy evaluation, even though device compliance isn't enforced. These prompts might repeat until the device is compliant. To prevent end users from receiving prompts during sign-in, exclude device platforms Mac, iOS, and Android from report-only policies that perform device compliance checks.\n+> Policies in report-only mode that require a compliant device can prompt users on macOS, iOS, and Android devices to select a device certificate during policy evaluation, even though device compliance isn't enforced. These prompts can repeat until the device is compliant. To prevent end users from receiving prompts during sign-in, exclude the Mac, iOS, and Android device platforms from report-only policies that perform device compliance checks.\n \n \n \n@@ -47,24 +48,24 @@ Administrators can use several options to review the potential results of polici\n \n - Workbooks\n - Sign-in logs\n-- Policy impact (Preview)\n+- Policy impact (preview)\n \n \n ### Policy impact\n \n-The policy impact view of Conditional Access lets admins with at least the Security Reader role see a snapshot of information about the potential or existing impacts of policies on interactive sign-ins in your organization. This functionality lets you explore impact over a period of the past 24 hours, 7 days, or 1 month. Additionally, you can see and link to a sampling of sign-in events for further detail.\n+The policy impact view of Conditional Access lets admins with at least the Security Reader role see a snapshot of the potential or existing impacts of policies on interactive sign-ins in your organization. You can explore the impact over the past 24 hours, 7 days, or 1 month. You can also see and link to a sampling of sign-in events for more details.\n \n :::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/concept-conditional-access-report-only/policy-impact-example-report-only.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot of Conditional Access policy impact example.\" lightbox=\"media/concept-conditional-access-report-only/policy-impact-example-report-only.png\":::\n \n \n \n ### Workbooks\n \n-Administrators can create multiple policies in report-only mode, so it's necessary to understand both the individual impact of each policy and the combined impact of multiple policies evaluated together. The [Conditional Access Insights and Reporting workbook](howto-conditional-access-insights-reporting.md) lets administrators visualize Conditional Access policy, it queries and monitor the impact of a policy for a given time range, set of applications, and users. Administrators can customize workbooks to suit their specific needs.\n+Administrators can create multiple policies in report-only mode, so it's important to understand both the individual impact of each policy and the combined impact of multiple policies evaluated together. The [Conditional Access Insights and Reporting workbook](howto-conditional-access-insights-reporting.md) lets administrators visualize Conditional Access policies, query and monitor the impact of a policy for a specific time range, set of applications, and users. Administrators can customize workbooks to meet their needs.\n \n ### Sign-in logs\n \n-For deeper evaluation of Conditional Access policies and their application at a specific sign-in, administrators might investigate individual sign-in events. Each of these events includes details of what Conditional Access policies were enabled versus were in report-only mode, and applied or didn't apply. \n+For deeper evaluation of Conditional Access policies and their application at a specific sign-in, administrators might investigate individual sign-in events. Each event includes details about which Conditional Access policies were enabled, in report-only mode, applied, or not applied. \n \n ![Screenshot showing the report-only tab in a sign-in log.](./media/concept-conditional-access-report-only/report-only-detail-in-sign-in-log.png)\n \n@@ -75,4 +76,4 @@ For deeper evaluation of Conditional Access policies and their application at a\n \n ## Related content\n \n-- [Configure report-only mode on a Conditional Access policy](howto-conditional-access-insights-reporting.md)\n+- Learn how to [configure report-only mode on a Conditional Access policy](howto-conditional-access-insights-reporting.md)." }, { "sha": "f9b94b94c60e221fdc92f91b98ac043b588b8ca7", "filename": "docs/identity/conditional-access/media/concept-conditional-access-report-only/policy-impact-example-report-only.png", "status": "modified", "additions": 0, "deletions": 0, "changes": 0, "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/ecca2938dca70fa763c53bb867428f3db75c2edd/docs%2Fidentity%2Fconditional-access%2Fmedia%2Fconcept-conditional-access-report-only%2Fpolicy-impact-example-report-only.png", "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/ecca2938dca70fa763c53bb867428f3db75c2edd/docs%2Fidentity%2Fconditional-access%2Fmedia%2Fconcept-conditional-access-report-only%2Fpolicy-impact-example-report-only.png", "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fidentity%2Fconditional-access%2Fmedia%2Fconcept-conditional-access-report-only%2Fpolicy-impact-example-report-only.png?ref=ecca2938dca70fa763c53bb867428f3db75c2edd" } ]. Please summarise it in a few sentences, using UK grammar and ensure the response is formatted for markdown. Do not start the response with here is summary.","role":"user"}
ai_summary.Response: The changes include updates to documentation regarding tenant restrictions, specifically addressing limitations with macOS Platform SSO and issues accessing the Microsoft Entra admin center. Additionally, documentation has been enhanced to include Microsoft Entra Internet Access and Private Access scenarios within the Security Copilot documentation, detailing how to investigate network traffic logs. Furthermore, adjustments have been made to clarify advanced options for passkeys (FIDO2) and certificate-based authentication in Conditional Access policies, including updated terminology and troubleshooting guidance. Finally, improvements have been made to the documentation on analyzing Conditional Access policy impact, emphasizing the use of report-only mode, Azure Monitor, and insights workbooks.

author: Shannon Leavitt
message:
Merge pull request #9700 from Justinha/auth-strength-edits

revised png and passkey FIDO2

ai_summary.Messages:
{"content":"The following is the commit files that have changed: [
  {

    "status": "modified",
    "additions": 16,

    "patch": "@@ -1,10 +1,10 @@\n ---\n-title: Overview of custom authentication strengths and advanced options for FIDO2 security keys and certificate-based authentication in Microsoft Entra ID\n-description: Learn how admins can create custom authentication strengths with advanced options for FIDO2 security keys and certificate-based authentication.\n+title: Overview of custom authentication strengths and advanced options for passkey (FIDO2) and certificate-based authentication in Microsoft Entra ID\n+description: Learn how admins can create custom authentication strengths with advanced options for passkey (FIDO2) security keys and certificate-based authentication.\n ms.service: entra-id\n ms.subservice: authentication\n ms.topic: article\n-ms.date: 03/04/2025\n+ms.date: 09/15/2025\n ms.author: justinha\n author: inbarckms\n manager: dougeby\n@@ -31,12 +31,12 @@ You can edit a custom authentication strength. If it's referenced by a Condition\n To check if an authentication strength is referenced by a Conditional Access policy, click the **Conditional Access policies** column.\n \n \n-## FIDO2 security key advanced options\n-You can restrict the usage of FIDO2 security keys based on their Authenticator Attestation GUIDs (AAGUIDs). This capability allows administrators to require a FIDO2 security key from a specific manufacturer in order to access the resource. To require a specific FIDO2 security key, first create a custom authentication strength. Then select **FIDO2 Security Key**, and click **Advanced options**. \n+## Passkey (FIDO2) advanced options\n+You can restrict the usage of passkeys (FIDO2) based on their Authenticator Attestation GUIDs (AAGUIDs). This capability allows administrators to require a FIDO2 security key from a specific manufacturer in order to access the resource. To require a specific FIDO2 security key, first create a custom authentication strength. Then select **Passkeys (FIDO2)**, and click **Advanced options**. \n \n-:::image type=\"content\" border=\"true\" source=\"./media/concept-authentication-strengths/key.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot showing Advanced options for FIDO2 security key.\":::\n+:::image type=\"content\" border=\"true\" source=\"./media/concept-authentication-strengths/key.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot showing Advanced options for passkey (FIDO2).\":::\n \n-Next to **Allowed FIDO2 Keys** click **+**, copy the AAGUID value, and click **Save**.\n+Next to **Add AAGUID**, click **+**, copy the AAGUID value, and click **Save**.\n \n :::image type=\"content\" border=\"true\" source=\"./media/concept-authentication-strengths/guid.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot showing how to add an Authenticator Attestation GUID.\":::\n \n@@ -62,12 +62,12 @@ The next sections show how to configure advanced options for CBA by using the Mi\n \n    :::image type=\"content\" border=\"true\" source=\"./media/concept-authentication-strength-advanced-options/certificate-advanced-options.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot showing Advanced options for certificate-based authentication.\":::\n     \n-1. You can select certificate issuers from the drop-down menu, type the certificate issuers and type the allowed policy OIDs. The drop-down menu lists all certificate authorities from the tenant irrespective of whether they're single-factor or multifactor. Certificate issuers can be configured either by using the drop down **Certificate issuers from the certificate authorities in your tenant** or by using **Other certificate issuer by SubjectkeyIdentifier** for scenarios where the certificate you would like to use is not uploaded to the Certificate authorities in your tenant. One such example is external user scenarios, where the user could be authenticating in their home tenant and auth strength is being enforced on the resource tenant.\n+1. You can select certificate issuers from the drop-down menu, type the certificate issuers and type the allowed policy OIDs. The drop-down menu lists all certificate authorities from the tenant irrespective of whether they're single-factor or multifactor. Certificate issuers can be configured either by using the drop-down **Certificate issuers from the certificate authorities in your tenant** or by using **Other certificate issuer by SubjectkeyIdentifier** for scenarios where the certificate you would like to use is not uploaded to the Certificate authorities in your tenant. One such example is external user scenarios, where the user could be authenticating in their home tenant and auth strength is being enforced on the resource tenant.\n \n-   :::image type=\"content\" border=\"true\" source=\"./media/concept-authentication-strength-advanced-options/or-other-issuer.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot showing the configuration options - certificate issuers from the drop-down menu, type the certificate issuers and type the allowed policy OIDs .\":::\n+   :::image type=\"content\" border=\"true\" source=\"./media/concept-authentication-strength-advanced-options/or-other-issuer.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot showing the configuration options - certificate issuers from the drop-down menu, type the certificate issuers and type the allowed policy OIDs.\":::\n \n    - If both attributes Certificate issuers AND  Policy OIDs are configured, there's a AND relationship and the user has to use a certificate that has atleast one of the issuers AND one of the policy OID from the list to satisfy the authentication strength.\n-   - If only Certificate issuers attribute is configured then the user has to use a certificate that has atleast one of the issuers to satisfy the authentication strength .\n+   - If only Certificate issuers attribute is configured then the user has to use a certificate that has atleast one of the issuers to satisfy the authentication strength.\n    - If only Policy OIDs attribute is configured then the user has to use a certificate that has atleast one of the policy OIDs to satisfy the authentication strength.\n \n   >[!NOTE]\n@@ -122,8 +122,8 @@ POST beta/identity/conditionalAccess/authenticationStrength/policies/{authentica\n \n ## Limitations\n \n-### FIDO2 security key advanced options\n-- FIDO2 security key Advanced options - Advanced options aren't supported for external users with a home tenant that is located in a different Microsoft cloud than the resource tenant.\n+### Passkeys (FIDO2) Advanced options\n+- Passkeys (FIDO2) Advanced options - Advanced options aren't supported for external users with a home tenant that is located in a different Microsoft cloud than the resource tenant.\n \n ### Certificate-based authentication advanced options\n \n@@ -136,7 +136,7 @@ POST beta/identity/conditionalAccess/authenticationStrength/policies/{authentica\n   >[!NOTE]\n   >If the certificate doesn't conform, user authentication might succeed, but not satisfy the issuerSki restrictions for the authentication strength policy.\n \n-- During sign-in, the first 5 policy OIDs from the end user certificate are considered, and compared with the policy OIDs configured in the authentication strength policy. If the end user certificate has more than 5 policy OIDs, the first 5 policy OIDs in lexical order that match the authentication strength requirements are taken into account. \n+- During sign-in, the first 5 policy OIDs from the end user certificate are considered, and compared with the policy OIDs configured in the authentication strength policy. If the end user certificate has more than five policy OIDs, the first five policy OIDs in lexical order that match the authentication strength requirements are taken into account. \n \n - For B2B users, let's take an example where Contoso has invited users from Fabrikam to their tenant. In this case, Contoso is the resource tenant and Fabrikam is the home tenant.\n   - When cross-tenant access setting is **Off** (Contoso doesn't accept MFA that was performed by the home tenant) - Using certificate-based authentication on the resource tenant isn't supported.\n@@ -147,10 +147,10 @@ POST beta/identity/conditionalAccess/authenticationStrength/policies/{authentica\n \n ## Troubleshooting  authentication strength advanced options\n \n-### Users can't use their FIDO2 security key to sign in\n-A Conditional Access Administrator can restrict access to specific security keys. When a user tries to sign in by using a key they can't use, this **You can't get there from here** message appears. The user has to restart the session, and sign-in with a different FIDO2 security key.\n+### Users can't use their passkey (FIDO2)  to sign in\n+A Conditional Access Administrator can restrict access to specific security keys. When a user tries to sign in by using a key they can't use, this **You can't get there from here** message appears. The user has to restart the session, and sign-in with a different passkey (FIDO2).\n \n-:::image type=\"content\" border=\"true\" source=\"./media/troubleshoot-authentication-strengths/restricted-security-key.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot of a sign-in error when using a restricted FIDO2 security key.\":::\n+:::image type=\"content\" border=\"true\" source=\"./media/troubleshoot-authentication-strengths/restricted-security-key.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot of a sign-in error when using a restricted passkey (FIDO2).\":::\n \n \n ### How to check certificate policy OIDs and issuer"

ai_summary.Response: The documentation has been updated to reflect the terminology change from "FIDO2 security keys" to "passkey (FIDO2)". This includes changes to the title, description, and various headings and image alt-texts within the document. Additionally, the date for the article has been updated to reflect the latest revision.
